default: Steel-cut oats, boiled egg, unsweetened almond milk
Grilled chicken breast, lentils, spinach salad
Grilled fish, brown rice, steamed broccoli
lactose: Lactose-free oats with berries, chia pudding, green tea
Grilled tofu, quinoa, spinach salad with lemon vinaigrette
Lentil soup with brown rice, steamed broccoli
anaphylaxis: Boiled eggs, gluten-free toast (rice or corn-based), herbal tea
Steamed fish (e.g., cod or tilapia), mashed potatoes, green salad with olive oil
Chicken stew with cooked carrots and millet

Workout.Activity: 20 min walk post-breakfast & post-dinner
15 min resistance band exercises focusing on major muscle groups
20 min brisk walk, light stretching (dynamic and static)
15 min resistance band exercises or bodyweight squats/lunges
30 min leisure walk, focusing on breathing
Yoga or Pilates for flexibility and core strength (20-30 min)
Rest or light activity like gardening (30 min)

general: No medication needed currently, focus on lifestyle modifications.
Maintain regular glucose testing annually or as advised by physician.
Medications.allergy: Avoid OTC multivitamins or supplements that may contain hidden allergens like lactose, gluten, or soy. Always check ingredient labels carefully.

default: Oatmeal with berries (low glycemic fruits), 1 boiled egg
Lean protein (grilled chicken/fish), large mixed greens salad, small portion of quinoa
Vegetable stir-fry with lean protein (tofu/chicken), brown rice
lactose: Oatmeal with plant-based milk, chia seeds, berries
Lentil soup, whole-grain bread (lactose-free), side salad
Rice cakes with avocado, cucumber slices
Baked salmon with roasted asparagus and sweet potato
anaphylaxis: Gluten-free cereal with safe milk substitute, banana
Turkey breast slices, boiled potatoes, steamed green beans
Lamb stew with carrots and peas, quinoa

Workout.Activity: 30 min brisk walking, focus on maintaining pace
20 min light resistance training (bodyweight exercises: squats, push-ups, planks)
30 min cycling (moderate intensity) or elliptical
20 min moderate resistance training, proper form emphasis
30 min walk or swim, focus on consistent effort
Yoga or stretching for 20-30 min, focusing on flexibility and balance
Active rest: light gardening, leisure walk (30-45 min)

general: Lifestyle modifications are primary focus.
Consider Metformin only if A1C continues to rise despite diet/exercise.
Monitor blood glucose levels 3 times a week.
Medications.allergy: Discuss all existing allergies with your doctor before starting any new medication, even over-the-counter.

default: Scrambled eggs with spinach, whole-wheat toast (small portion), black coffee
Baked chicken with large serving of non-starchy vegetables (broccoli, bell peppers)
Lentil and vegetable curry, small portion of brown rice
lactose: Tofu scramble with vegetables, gluten-free toast
Quinoa salad with chickpeas, cucumber, tomato, and olive oil dressing
Vegetable stir-fry with tempeh, small serving of wild rice
anaphylaxis: Boiled egg, plain rice porridge (made with water), safe fruit
Baked cod with boiled carrots and green beans
Chicken and vegetable broth-based soup with rice noodles

Workout.Activity: 20 min walk after breakfast and dinner, focus on steady pace
15 min light resistance band exercises, focus on upper body
30 min moderate walking or stationary bike
15 min light resistance band exercises, focus on lower body
20 min leisure walk, gentle stretching
Light stretching or seated exercises (20 min)
Rest or very light activity (e.g., household chores)

general: Metformin 500mg once daily, gradually increase as tolerated.
Regular blood glucose monitoring: fasting, pre-meal, and 2-hour post-meal.
HbA1c test every 3-6 months.
Medications.allergy: Report any new symptoms (e.g., rash, swelling, difficulty breathing) immediately, as these could indicate an allergic reaction to medication. Keep an antihistamine handy if advised by doctor.

Treatment: Start Metformin 500mg after dinner to minimize GI upset.
Strict dietary control: emphasis on whole foods, low glycemic index, portion control.
Blood glucose log: record levels before breakfast and 2 hours after dinner daily.
Increase Metformin to 500mg twice daily (after breakfast and dinner), if tolerated.
Monitor for gastrointestinal upset (nausea, diarrhea).
Introduce walking 30 minutes per day, gradually increasing intensity.
Continue Metformin dosage as tolerated.
Consider adding a sulfonylurea (e.g., Gliclazide) if glucose targets are not met, under medical supervision.
Schedule HbA1c test and kidney function panel.
Review HbA1c and kidney function results with doctor.
Adjust medication doses based on results; consider additional agents like SGLT2 inhibitors if needed.
Continue consistent diet and exercise, monitor weight progress.

default: Steel-cut oats, boiled egg, unsweetened almond milk
Grilled chicken breast, lentils, spinach salad
Grilled fish, brown rice, steamed broccoli
lactose: Oats in oat milk, boiled egg, handful of berries
Tofu stir-fry with mixed vegetables (broccoli, bell peppers), green beans, lentils
Quinoa with chickpeas and roasted vegetables (zucchini, eggplant)
anaphylaxis: Boiled eggs, gluten-free toast (e.g., rice bread), green tea
Baked chicken breast, plain white rice, steamed mixed vegetables (carrots, peas)
Steamed fish (e.g., basa), plain boiled potatoes, cooked carrots

Workout.Activity: 20 min walk post-breakfast & post-dinner, slow to moderate pace.
15 min walk + 10 min resistance band exercises (light weights/bands for arms and legs).
20 min walk, light yoga for blood sugar control and stress reduction.
Brisk walking 25 min + core activation exercises (e.g., gentle planks, bird-dog).
Walk stairs 10 min (slow, controlled) + toe touches, side bends (seated or standing).
Stretching & flexibility routine (20 min), focus on large muscle groups.
Rest or 20 min leisure walk with ample hydration and comfortable shoes.

general: Metformin 500mg twice daily (commonly prescribed and cornerstone therapy).
Monitor blood glucose before and after meals, and at bedtime.
Monthly HbA1c checks to assess long-term glucose control.
Regular visits with endocrinologist for dosage adjustments and new medication introduction.
Medications.allergy: Ensure all medications are allergy-safe. Avoid sulfa-containing drugs (e.g., some sulfonylureas) if allergic to sulfa. Always inform your doctor and pharmacist of all known allergies.

Treatment: Start Metformin 500mg after dinner to reduce initial gastrointestinal side effects.
Strict dietary control: adherence to no-sugar, low glycemic index foods, precise portion control.
Blood glucose log: meticulously record levels before breakfast, before dinner, and 2 hours after meals.
Increase Metformin to 500mg twice daily (after breakfast and dinner), if tolerated well.
Actively monitor for any GI upset (nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain); report persistent issues.
Incorporate walking 30 minutes per day, aiming for consistency and gradual increase in pace.

Continue Metformin at current dose. If glucose targets are still not met, discuss with doctor about adding a DPP-4 Inhibitor (e.g., Sitagliptin 50mg daily) or a GLP-1 Receptor Agonist (e.g., Liraglutide).
Schedule HbA1c test and comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) to check kidney and liver function.
Review HbA1c results and CMP with your healthcare provider.
Adjust medication doses or consider adding an SGLT2 inhibitor (e.g., Empagliflozin) if blood glucose remains high, especially if there are cardiovascular or renal benefits to be gained.
Regularly check kidney function, monitor weight progress, and discuss any new symptoms.

default: Grilled chicken wrap (whole wheat), leafy greens, fruit salad
Baked salmon, quinoa, roasted mixed vegetables (broccoli, bell peppers, zucchini)
lactose: Oatmeal with plant milk (almond/soy/oat), boiled egg
Lentil soup, brown rice, spinach salad with lemon dressing
Tofu stir fry with couscous and grilled peppers
anaphylaxis: Scrambled eggs, gluten-free bread (e.g., pure rice bread)
Baked chicken breast (skinless), mashed potatoes (made with water/safe broth), carrots
Steamed white fish (e.g., cod), plain rice, green beans

Workout: 30 minutes moderate-intensity walk daily (e.g., brisk enough to raise heart rate but still hold a conversation).
2-3 times per week strength training with light weights or resistance bands (focus on major muscle groups, 10-15 repetitions).
Avoid holding breath during exercise (Valsalva maneuver) to prevent spikes in blood pressure.
Include 5-10 minutes of warm-up and cool-down stretches for each session.

general: No medications required currently, focus on maintaining healthy lifestyle.
Maintain blood pressure and cholesterol through a balanced, heart-healthy diet and regular exercise.
Annual physical check-up including lipid profile and blood pressure monitoring.
Medications.allergy: Avoid NSAIDs (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs) if you have a history of allergic asthma or aspirin sensitivity, as they can exacerbate symptoms. Consult with your doctor for pain relief alternatives.

default: Oatmeal with flaxseed, berries, skim milk
Large salad with grilled fish (salmon/sardines), olive oil dressing
Small handful of walnuts, green tea
lactose: Oatmeal with almond milk, chia seeds, sliced banana
Vegetable and lentil soup, gluten-free bread
Soy yogurt (plain), handful of sunflower seeds
Grilled eggplant, tomato, and zucchini with couscous
anaphylaxis: Boiled egg, rice cakes, herbal tea
Baked turkey, plain mashed potatoes (made with water), steamed carrots
Steamed chicken, plain white rice, boiled green beans

Workout: 30-40 minutes moderate-intensity cardiovascular exercise daily (e.g., brisk walking, swimming).
3 times per week strength training with light-to-moderate weights, focusing on controlled movements and higher repetitions (12-15 reps).
Incorporate mindfulness or light yoga for stress reduction and improved heart rate variability (20 minutes, 2x/week).

general: Lifestyle modifications are paramount.
Consider low-dose aspirin (e.g., 81mg) if a doctor advises based on individual risk factors (e.g., high cholesterol, family history).
Regular monitoring of blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels (e.g., quarterly).
Medications.allergy: Always inform your healthcare provider about any allergies to medications (e.g., aspirin, ibuprofen) before new prescriptions. Anaphylaxis history requires careful consideration of all medications.

default: Oatmeal with flaxseed, berries, skim milk
Large salad with grilled fish (salmon/sardines), olive oil dressing
Small handful of walnuts, green tea
lactose: Oatmeal with almond milk, chia seeds, sliced banana
Vegetable and lentil soup, gluten-free bread
Soy yogurt (plain), handful of sunflower seeds
Grilled eggplant, tomato, and zucchini with couscous
anaphylaxis: Boiled egg, rice cakes, herbal tea
Baked turkey, plain mashed potatoes (made with water), steamed carrots
Steamed chicken, plain white rice, boiled green beans

Workout.Activity: 30 min moderate walking, broken into two 15-min sessions if needed.
20 min light circuit training (e.g., wall push-ups, chair squats, bicep curls with light weights).
30 min cycling (stationary bike) at a comfortable pace.
20 min light resistance training, focusing on controlled movements and breathing.
30 min walking or elliptical, maintaining a consistent heart rate zone.
Gentle stretching and balance exercises (20-25 min).
Rest or light active recovery (e.g., 20 min leisurely stroll).

general: Individualized medication based on risk factors (e.g., blood pressure, cholesterol).
Often includes a low-dose statin (e.g., Atorvastatin 10mg) for cholesterol management.
May include a low-dose ACE inhibitor (e.g., Lisinopril 5mg) or ARB if blood pressure is consistently elevated.
Regular monitoring of blood pressure (daily), lipid profile (every 6 months), and kidney function.
Medications.allergy: If allergic to statins, discuss alternative lipid-lowering agents (e.g., ezetimibe, PCSK9 inhibitors) with your doctor. If ACE inhibitor causes cough, an ARB is usually a safe alternative.

Treatment: Start Atorvastatin 10mg nightly for cholesterol control.
Monitor blood pressure twice daily (morning and evening) and record readings.
Adhere strictly to a low-sodium, low-saturated fat diet.
Introduce Lisinopril 5mg once daily in the morning if blood pressure remains elevated.
Continue Atorvastatin. Monitor for side effects (e.g., muscle pain from statin, dry cough from ACE inhibitor).
Increase daily physical activity to 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise.
Continue all prescribed medications. Ensure adherence and address any side effects with your doctor.
Schedule a follow-up appointment with your physician to review medication efficacy and tolerance.
Blood tests: lipid panel, electrolytes, and kidney function tests.
Review lab results and adjust medication dosages as needed.
Discuss potential for adding a low-dose aspirin (75mg) if cardiovascular risk assessment warrants it.
Consider referral to a nutritionist for detailed dietary guidance.

default: Oatmeal with flaxseed, boiled egg white, unsweetened almond milk
Grilled salmon, sweet potato (small portion), large kale salad with light dressing
Carrot sticks, small portion of unsalted almonds
Steamed chicken breast (skinless), brown rice, steamed broccoli and green beans
lactose: Oats with oat milk, apple, sprinkle of cinnamon
Tofu salad with mixed greens, lentil stew (low sodium)
Grilled eggplant, quinoa, zucchini, and bell pepper medley
anaphylaxis: Boiled egg, plain rice cakes, green tea
Baked chicken breast (plain), white rice, boiled spinach
Apple slices, plain, salt-free crackers (e.g., rice crackers)
Steamed fish (e.g., flounder), plain mashed potato (made with water), cooked carrots

Workout.Activity: 10 min walk after every meal (3x/day), light stretching for 5 min.
15 min walk post-lunch, 10 min gentle yoga focusing on breathing and relaxation.
10 min walk 2x/day, guided deep breathing exercises (5-10 min) for stress management.
20 min physiotherapist-guided cardiac rehab exercises, focusing on low-impact movements.
15 min walk + arm/leg lifts (seated or supported standing, slow and controlled).
10 min stair climbing (slow pace, holding handrail), gentle yoga or stretching for 15 min.
Rest day or 15 min leisure walk at a very comfortable pace, ensuring good hydration.

general: Beta-blockers (e.g., Metoprolol) for heart rate control, blood pressure, and rhythm management.
Statins for aggressive cholesterol reduction (high-intensity statin like Atorvastatin 40-80mg or Rosuvastatin 20-40mg).
ACE inhibitors (e.g., Lisinopril) or ARBs (e.g., Valsartan) if ejection fraction is < 50% or for blood pressure control.
Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide) for fluid retention, if present.
Aspirin (low-dose, 75-100mg daily) for antiplatelet effect, unless contraindicated.
Medications.allergy: If an ACE inhibitor causes a persistent dry cough, ask your doctor for an alternative medication from the ARB class (e.g., Valsartan, Losartan) which has a similar effect without the cough. Be vigilant for any signs of allergic reactions to new medications and report them immediately.

Treatment: Start Beta-blocker (Metoprolol Succinate ER 25mg daily) for heart rate and BP control.
Start high-intensity Statin (Atorvastatin 40mg nightly) for cholesterol reduction.
Low-dose Aspirin 75mg daily (if advised by doctor based on risk-benefit).
Monitor blood pressure and heart rate twice daily and keep a detailed record.
Increase Beta-blocker dose (Metoprolol 50mg daily) if tolerated and BP/HR targets not met.
Add ACE Inhibitor (Enalapril 2.5mg morning) if blood pressure remains high or for heart failure indication.
Continue Statin and Aspirin. Monitor for signs of hypotension or excessive bradycardia.
Schedule blood tests for electrolytes (potassium, sodium), kidney function (creatinine, BUN), and liver enzymes.
Continue all current medications. If fluid retention is present, a loop diuretic (e.g., Furosemide 20mg daily) might be initiated.
Regularly monitor ECG response to therapy if symptoms persist or worsen.
Weekly weight check for fluid retention, strict adherence to sodium-restricted diet.
Adjust Enalapril or Metoprolol dose if blood pressure is too low or symptoms persist. If cough develops with ACEI, switch to ARB.
Consider referral to a specialized cardiologist for advanced management or further diagnostic tests.
If stable, consider a supervised treadmill stress test to assess cardiac function under exertion.
Follow-up lab work: Lipid profile, repeat ECG, and follow-up consultation with cardiologist.
